utterances: Well, I think the two countries I would push in that category are Portugal, which is to some extent there already...
Right.
It's just a whole new perspective, like I can see over stuff now.
I'm taller than the refrigerator.
Like, I don't have to kill myself trying to get something out of the freezer.
And how big a deal was this for the Los Angeles Times, Patt Morrison?
Officials in the Obama administration say if those Patriot Act provisions do expire, they would lose important counterterrorism tools.
Still, they appear resigned to seeing those legal authorities sunset at midnight on Sunday for what they hope will be only a few days.
Their assumption seems to be that this Republican-run Congress won't let these national security powers lapse for long on its watch.
But the only way to avert such a lapse is if the Senate on Sunday evening approves the same bill passed by the House.
Unless both Kentucky senators drop their opposition, that likely won't happen.
David Welna, NPR News, Washington.
New unemployment and employment numbers come out for December tomorrow.
And today, we'll try to figure out what perspective we should have on those numbers.
Now, in the previous month's report, the unemployment rate dropped to 7.7 percent, which is a four-year low.
Nariman Behravesh is chief economist at IHS Global Insight, an international consulting firm.
And he says it may be time to rethink what a good unemployment number is.
We start here with a definition of full employment.
Well, full employment is defined as basically everybody who's looking for a job or is looking to be employed is, in fact, employed.
The first time I ever heard of this concept - when I was a teenager, maybe -people talked about full employment as being about a 5 percent unemployment rate.
They didn't think of the zero percent unemployment rate.
They said 5 percent.
Well, and there are issues that won't ever get us down to zero.
There's something called frictional unemployment, which is to say there's always going to be people between jobs.
So at any given moment, there will be people who are out of a job and looking for a job.
There's sort of structural employment issues in the sense that there may be some high-skilled that are waiting to be filled, but a lot of low-skilled workers who won't get those jobs.

So there's always going to be some people who are going to be out there who can't quite find a job, but for very sort of straightforward reasons, not because the economy is a mess or because we're in a recession or anything like that.
OK.
So there's some number that's above zero that feels like full employment, or is awfully close to that, that's realistic to hope for.
Has that number changed over time as the economy has changed?
That is a number that does change.
It changes with demographics.
It changes with the business cycle, to some extent.
So, for example, in the boom years of the 1990s and the 2000s, a lot of economists thought the unemployment - the full employment-unemployment rate was around 4 percent.
Now the view is that just given all the changes that have occurred since the financial crisis, it may be closer to 6 percent.
So it is a number that changes
OK.
This is disturbing to hear, because in the early 2000s, there was a recession - as you know very well - and the unemployment rate went up to six percent or so, and that was considered very, very bad.
And now you're saying that that might be full employment in our changed economy?
That might be the best we can hope for, is six?
Now, the 2000-2001 recession was one of the mildest in the postwar period, whereas, of course, the recession we just went through was the worst since the Great Depression.
So it is ironic that the high at that point of 6 percent is now viewed as full employment, basically.
It's a little disturbing, but I think that's just the reality of where we are right now, relative to stay where we were four or five years ago.
OK.
So we've got the situation where six percent might be the best that we can aim for.
We're in the sevens right now.
At least it has, in recent months, been moving in the right direction.
What would move it further in the right direction?
Well, certainly, sustained growth ideally closer to 3 percent would help to bring the number down.

Unfortunately, over the next year, we're probably only going to get about 2 percent growth, which means the unemployment rate is going to be stuck around sort of seven-and-a-half, maybe a little higher, for probably the better part of this year.
But then our view is that the underlying strength in the economy will eventually start to kick in, as housing recovers, as consumer spending picks up, as businesses start to spend.
So by the end of 2014, we have a shot at getting below seven and hopefully heading towards that full employment number of 6 percent.
Are we never going to get to that 1990s-style 4 percent unemployment again in this country?
I think a 4 percent number is probably unattainable in the next, say, five to six years.
Again, a lot depends on sort of how the structure of the economy changes.
You can never say never.
But I would say in the coming decade, we probably will have a very hard time getting down to that 4 percent.
Nariman Behravesh is author of ""Spin-Free Economics."" Thanks very much.
My pleasure.
This back to biology class and you may remember learning about exoskeletons.
They're the hard outer structures that provide protection for creatures like beetles and lobsters.
Technology has now given us exoskeletons for humans.
Several companies have developed devices to give people super-human abilities, like carrying very heavy loads.
And as Erin Toner of member station WUWM in Milwaukee reports, these robotic suits are also helping people who are paralyzed.
Army veteran Dan Rose has spent the last three years in a wheelchair, after an explosion in Afghanistan left him paralyzed from the chest down.
Doctors told the then-26-year-old, he'd never walk again.
Well, things turned out a little differently.
All right, Dan.
You ready to stand up?
Yep.
Yep.
Here we go: 1, 2, 3.
All righty.
Rose, with long brown hair tucked under a backwards baseball cap, is standing in his apartment in Madison with the help of his new motorized exoskeleton suit.
It looks like something Hollywood actors wear in sci-fi movies.
His cousin, Nick Roush, places Rose's feet in bindings, tightens Velcro straps around his legs and chest and locks the suit's hip joints.
When everything's secure, Rose is ready to move.
And stepping.
(SOUNDBITE OF MACHINE MOVING)
It even sounds like a robot.
Rose takes slow, stilted steps by carefully positioning each leg, shifting his weight and then triggering the exo-suit to move by pushing buttons on a pair of crutches.
It told you when to have sex?
It just told me when I was more fertile.
...and much more worrying, Spain, because Spain is a big economy - is the third biggest economy and the eurozone.
So that's the one to watch.
But they are clearly in a position where the economy is shrinking.
They've been told to implement deeper austerity, and that seems simply to make the economy shrink even more.
Does nobody see this happening?
I mean you're saying that hardly anyone seems to be proposing seriously another way out?
The problem is that Spain is in a real bind because it's very difficult for the government to borrow anymore.
But some Spanish leaders are appealing to the Germans and others to allow them to borrow a bit more under the terms of the rules of the European Commission.
It's just - Spain has gotten into a very difficult situation today and getting out of it is going to require a lot of work and a quite a lot of pain.
John Peet of The Economist Magazine.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
There's been more violence today in Thailand on the streets of the capital, Bangkok.
Protestors continue their campaign to bring down the government.
For eight days now, thousands of people have occupied or besieged government offices, trying to unseat Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.
Today, protestors tried to overrun and occupy the symbolic seat of power, Government House, but police thwarted the move with tear gas and rubber-coated bullets.
Demonstrators vow to keep at it until the government falls.
Yingluck says she's willing to talk, but she will not step down.
For more on this, we're joined by reporter Michael Sullivan in Bangkok.
And Michael, it's said this protest is more about the prime minister's brother than about the present government.
How's that?
That's right.
It's Groundhog Day here in Thailand.
In 2006, Robert, protestors in Bangkok turned out in big numbers to demand the resignation of then Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.
He's Yingluck's older brother.
And they accused him of corruption and abuse of power.
And when he didn't step down, the army stepped in and removed him and then wrote a new constitution aimed at keeping Thaksin and his kind out of power.
But it didn't work.
He fled the country in 2008 after his conviction on corruption charges.
He remains hugely popular among the rural majority and the urban poor.
The opposition says Yingluck, his sister, is just her brother's puppet, that he's Skyping it in from exile in Dubai.
But I have to stress this, it's a minority effort to unseat the current democratically elected government and it's still about him.
They hate him, full stop.
As you say, there's been a history of political violence in Thailand.
What is this government's strategy in response to these protests?

Extremely cautious because they don't know where to go next because they know that if they use excessive force against the protestors then that will give the army - the army has a tradition here of engineering coups.
They've had 18 coup attempts here in the last several decades.
And the army could step in, in case the police actually move against the protesters in a very determined way.
And the army can then say, OK, we've done what we need to do to restore the order here and to maintain Thailand as a country and to maintain the monarchy.
Let's not forget the idea of the monarchy, which is very important here.
So Yingluck Shinawatra and her government have to be very careful not to use excessive force against the demonstrators because if they do that, then the army could find an excuse to step in.
And Michael, you mentioned the Thai monarchy.
Have the royals taken any position on all of this?
Are they seen as partisan to one side or the other?
Absolutely no response from the monarchy.
All they say, in very general terms, is that Thailand should be a peaceful country and we should resolve all our problems peacefully.
But the king is 86 years old, or will soon be 86 years old.
He'll actually be 86 on Thursday and there is some question about the succession here and the Thai politics, the monarchy, very sensitive subject here.
So it's unclear where the monarchy stands on this issue, but in the past, frankly, in 2008 and 2006, they were seen as siding very much with the army on the side against Thaksin.
Well, the protesters have set a deadline for the prime minister to go.
She says she's not going anywhere.
Is the violence likely to increase in that case?
I have no absolutely no idea.
But with a deadline looming, I have doubts whether things will be peaceful.

I think given what happened on Sunday and given what happened again today, I think the demonstrators are probably going to ratchet up their efforts in the next two days before the king's birthday to try to get Yingluck to capitulate.
Whether she does or doesn't, unclear at this point.
That's Michael Sullivan, reporting from Bangkok.
Michael, thanks.
You're welcome, Robert.
